title: Add warning for unnecessary imports

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.

If you cannot produce a minimal reproduction case (something that would work in
isolation), please provide the steps or even link to a repository that causes
the problematic output to occur.
-->

Given the following code: <!-- Please provide a link to play.rust-lang.org -->

```rust
use foo::*;
use foo::bar;

// ...
```

The current output is:

Nothing, assuming the modules exist and are used.

Ideally the output should look like:

```
warning: unnecessary import: `foo::bar`
 --> src\main.rs:2:5
  |
2 | use foo::bar;
  |     ^^^^^^^^
  |
  = note: `#[warn(unnecessary_imports)]` on by default
```

This sort of thing is fairly innocuous, but still probably merits a warning.

Incidentally, this:

```rust
use foo::bar;
use foo::bar;

// ...
```

Generates the output:

```
error[E0252]: the name `bar` is defined multiple times
 --> src\main.rs:2:5
  |
1 | use foo::bar;
  |     -------- previous import of the <module/type/value> `bar` here
2 | use foo::bar;
  |     ^^^^^^^^ `bar` reimported here
  |
  = note: `bar` must be defined only once in the <type/value> namespace of this module
```

And this:

```rust
use foo::{bar,baz};
use foo::bar;

// ...
```

Generates the same sort of thing:

```
error[E0252]: the name `bar` is defined multiple times
 --> src\main.rs:2:5
  |
1 | use foo::{bar,baz};
  |           --- previous import of the <module/type/value> `bar` here
2 | use foo::bar;
  |     ^^^^^^^^ `bar` reimported here
  |
  = note: `bar` must be defined only once in the <type/value> namespace of this module
```

So maybe it should be an extension of error E0252 rather than a warning?
